questions.text: A child was brought to the pediatric ward. Height of the child was <3rd percentile according to growth charts. On further examination his upper segment: lower segment ratio (US:LS) was found to be not normal. Which of the following condition explains the above scenario?
questions.solution:
2 Types of short stature

  1. Proportionate: US: LS ratio remains Normal
  2. Disproportionate: US: LS change

Disproportionate short stature

Short trunk dwarfism (US: LS Decreases) Short Limb Dwarfism (US: LS Increases)
  • Mnemonic: “Short Man May Climb High”
  • Spondylo-Epiphyseal Dysplasia
  • Mucopolysaccharidosis
  • Mucolipidosis
  • Caries spine (Pott’s disease)
  • Vertebral defects like hemivertebrae, butterfly vertebrae etc.
  • seen in Alagille syndrome
  • triangular facies (also seen in Russell Silver syndrome)
  • butterfly vertebra
  • pulmonary stenosis
  • cholestatic jaundice
  • Rickets
  • Achondroplasia
  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta
  • Congenital Hypothyroidism

9 months Speaks bisyllables eg mama, papa, but without meaning
12 months Speaks 2-3 words with meaning; Imitates simple sounds;

questions.text: A newborn child had respiratory distress and scaphoid abdomen. On chest Xray mediastinal shift and pulmonary hypoplasia was noted. Which of the following is not a predictor of poor outcome of this condition?
questions.solution:
Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia:

What is it:

  • A diaphragmatic defect through which abdominal contents may herniate into thorax.
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia
  • Intestinal malrotation

Associated With:

  • Esophageal atresia
  • Congenital heart diseases
  • Omphalocele
  • Trisomy 13,18

Most commontype —postero-lateral or Bockdalek variety

Most commonon left side: Most commonin females

Clinical Features

At Birth, usually presents with a TRIAD:

  • Respiratory distress
  • Scaphoid Abdomen
  • Mediastinal shift

Later in life - Intestinal obstruction

Diagnosis:

  1. Clinical features
  2. Antenatal USC (between 16-24 weeks)
  3. Chest X-Ray
    • Bowel gas shadows in thorax
    • mediastinal shift
    • Pulmonary hypoplasia

Predictors of Poor Outcome in Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia:

  1. Severe pulmonary hypoplasia
  2. Lung head ratio (LHR) <1
  3. Any malformation associated
  4. Symptoms in 1" 24 hrs
  5. Liver into thorax
  6. EMCO need

questions.text: During performing an autopsy inflow outflow method of heart-dissection. Which heart chamber was dissected into first?
questions.solution:
Heart Dissection

  • Inflow outflow method: Start cutting from RA → RV → LA →LV

Autopsy Techniques Advantage Disadvantage
Letulle’s Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed"en masse," as one big organ block.
  • The best technique to see relations amongst organs.
  • Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other
  • Rapid technique
 Difficult to handle large mass.
Ghon’s Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks(en block) This method can also be used in Infants
Virchow’s Organs are removedone by one Most commonly used technique (easier to perform) Anatomical relations of organs are not preserved
Rokitansky In situdissection (inside the body itself)

Good for

  • infected bodies like HIV, Hepatitis B (prevents spreading of infection)
  • Radiation hazards
  • Fetal brain dissection

questions.solution:
In the given condition injury is simple and is caused by a dangerous weapon, hence 324 IPC

IPC Sections related to Hurt etc: -

  • 319 -Definition of Hurt (Any Bodily pain, Infirmity or Disease)
  • 320 -Definition of Grievous hurt.
  • 321-Defines Voluntarily causing hurt
  • 322-Defines Voluntarily causing Grievous hurt
  • 323 -Punishment for causing hurt: Up to 1 year, fine up to 1000 Rs
  • 324-Punishment for causing Hurt by dangerous weapon: Up to 03 years, or fine
  • 325-Punishment for causing Grievous hurt: Up to 07 years, and also fine.
  • 326-Punishment for Grievous hurt by dangerous weapons: Imprisonment for life, or up to 10 yrs., and fine
  • 326 -A Causing grievous hurt by throwing acid: Minimum ten years and maximum upto life
  • 326 -B Throwing or attempting to throw acid: Minimum 5 years and maximum upto 7 years)
  • 330-Causing hurt to extort confession, or to compel restoration of property.
  • 331 -Causing grievous hurt to extort confession, or to compel restoration of property.

  • 335 -Punishment for Grievous hurt on provocation: Up to 04 years or with fine up to 2000 rupees

questions.text: A patient who had eczema also complained of recurrent infections. On blood examination thrombocytopenia was noted and IG-M levels were low. What is the mode of inheritance of the given disease?
questions.solution:
Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome·

  • X-linked disordercharacterized by eczema, a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection and thrombocytopenia resulting in early death and is provedfatal.
  • There is continuousloss of T-Cellsin the blood and in the T-cell zones (paracortical areas), with other variable defects in cellular immunity.
  • IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are mostly normal. Paradoxically the levels ofIgA and IgE are often elevated.
  • Patients do not make antibodies to the polysaccharide antigens, and the response to these protein antigens is poor. Rx: -Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant.

questions.text: Which cytokine is responsible recruitment of neutrophils?
questions.solution:

  • IL2 – autocrine action: ­ T- lymphocytes
  • IL4 - B cell proliferation & differentiation
  • IL6 – systemic effects of inflammation
  • IL7 – normal functioning of B/T cell [defect causes SCID]
  • IL11 - ­ platelets
  • IL3 – hematopoietic precursor cell proliferation
  • IL10 – anti-inflammatory action
  • IL17 – secretes by T-cells, responsible for the recruitment of neutrophils eg – in hepatitis, Kaposi’s sarcoma

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with a complaint of fatigue and bone pain. On radiological examination, an anterior mediastinal mass was seen. On examination, drooping eyelids were observed. What will be the result of the biopsy?
questions.solution:
Given clinical features suggests the diagnosis of Myasthenia gravis.

Myasthenia gravis

  • Acquired autoimmune disease characterized by abnormal muscular fatigability, caused by circulating antibodies to acetylcholine receptor at myoneural junction [post-synaptic].
  • Manifests with ptosis (drooping eyelids) or diplopia (double vision) because of weakness in extraocular muscles.
  • Pattern of weakness is distinctly different from most primary myopathic diseases, in which there is relative sparing of facial & extraocular muscles.
  • Repetitive firing of muscles makes weakness more severe, whereas cholinesterase inhibitors improve strength markedly
  • diagnostically useful.
  • In 2/3rd of patients, thymic hyperplasia is closely associated with myasthenia gravis & 15% have thymoma.
  • Conversely, 1/3rd to 1/2 of patients with thymoma develop myasthenia gravis.
  • Thymectomy is often an effective treatment for these patients.
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors, immunosuppression, plasmapheresis can also be used in treatment.

questions.text: A patient presented with shortness of breath, diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, and hot flushes. On further examination, hepatomegaly and pitting edema of lower legs was noted. 24hr urinary sample showed raised level of 5-HIAA. A cardiac echo will show which of the following?
questions.solution: Carcinoid syndrome refers to the release of active tumor products and features diarrhoea, flushing, bronchospasm and skin lesions. Carcinoid heart disease typically affects the right side of the heart, causing changes in thepulmonary and tricuspid valves. It is associated with intestinal carcinoids that have metastasized to the liver. The cardiac lesions consist of plaque-like deposits of dense fibrous tissue on the tricuspid valve and pulmonary valves, producing tricuspid insufficiency and pulmonic stenosis. Elevated levels of HIAAA, a metabolite of serotonin, are diagnostic of carcinoid syndrome. The other options are not complications of carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text: Patient complaints of severe pruritis while taking a hot shower and presents with deep vein thrombosis. On biochemical investigation it was noted that there was a change in amino acids, valine was replaced by phenylalanine. Following is the picture of marrow seen in this patient. What will be the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Polycythaemia vera

  • Characterized by a change in Amino acids
  • There is a replacement of valine by phenylalanine
  • Mutation = JAK 2 Mutation
  • In the early stage there is a proliferation of all cell lines k/a Panmyelosis.
  • In this image there is increased cellularity this is seen due to the proliferation of all cell lines.
  • However, in later stages due to excessive fibrosis in marrow which is called as a spent phase.
  • In this image blue colour depicts fibrosis of marrow k/a spent phase.

Clinical features:

  • Headache, dizziness, hypertension, Intense pruritus and peptic ulceration possibly resulting from the release of histamine from basophils.
  • Hot showers will result in degranulation of the basophils thus releasing histamines.

questions.text: A biopsy was taken of a CNS tumor which revealed the image given below. Pathologists described capillaries as “chicken wire capillaries.” What will the disease be?
questions.solution:
Oligodendroglioma:

  • The tumors are composed of spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin(similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm giving a 'fried egg' appearance.
  • The tumor typically contains a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries ('chicken-wire' capillaries).
  • Perinuclear satellitosis is a feature of oligodendroglioma.
  • Most commonly presented in the fourth and fifth decades.
  • The lesion is mostly found in the cerebral hemispheres (in temporal or frontal lobes).

Image on the left shows perinuclear halos giving rise to a 'fried-egg' appearance.

Image on the right shows Perineuronal satellitosis.

questions.text: The image describes which of the following?
questions.solution:
• 'Photoelectric effect'or 'photoelectric absorption(PEA)' is a form of interaction of X-ray or gamma photon with the matter. A low-energy photon interacts with the electron in the atom and removes it from its inner shell. Molybdenum is used in mammography.
  • 'Thermionic emission'-the emission of electrons from a heated source, occurs at the cathode.
  • 'Bremsstrahlung radiation'-When bombarding electrons penetrate into the target, some electrons travel close to the nucleus and the course of these electrons would be deflected, and a portion or all of their kinetic energy would be lost. The 'lost' energy is emitted as X-ray photons.
  • Compton effect-is responsible for scattering radiation

questions.text: A patient went under sentinel lymph node biopsy and nerve was injured. Which nerve is most commonly injured during this procedure?
questions.solution:
Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB):

  • First described by Cabana in CA penis
  • SLNB is the standard care of management of melanoma and breast cancer
  • The first node to receive drainage from the tumour site is termed the sentinel node
  • SLNB is primarily used to assess the regional lymph nodes in women with early breast cancer who are clinically node negative by physical examination and imaging studies
  • The combination of isosulfan blue dye and technetium labelled sulphur colloid improves the capability of detecting sentinel node
  • C/I of SLN biopsy:
    • Palpable lymphadenopathy
    • Prior axillary surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy
    • Multifocal breast cancer
    • Inflammatory breast cancers
  • Radio-labelled colloid technique is safe in pregnancy
  • Most of SLN of breast located in level 1
  • Most commonly injured in SLN biopsy is intercostobrachial nerve

questions.text: Several types of gastrointestinal autografts have been used for the reconstruction of the esophagus following esophagectomy for esophageal carcinoma. Most successful reconstructions have been achieved by which of the following autograft?
questions.solution:
Ideally the conduit substituting for the oesophagus should mimic as closely as possible to the normal esophagus to preserve quality of life

The conduit of choice for esophagus is in the order ofStomach>colon>jejunum

Stomach

Today stomach is by farthe most preferred conduitfor replacing the esophagus in over 95% of cases. It is the quickest and simplest organ surgery for reconstruction. It has a robust arterial and venous supply and submucosal plexus. There is only the need for asingle anastomosis.As the stomach is flexible, it can easily reach the neck for a cervical or even hypopharyngeal anastomoses. Its main disadvantage is the potential of reflux and related aspiration problems. After mobilisation, the stomach will receive its blood supply from the right gastroepiploic artery

Colon

It is thesecondoption substitute when the stomach cannot be used or when the stomach has to be respected for oncological reasons. The main advantage of colon is its versatility. The length is freely available for replacement of the entire oesophagus upto the pharynx. The blood supply is from the left colic artery and the presence of a marginal artery, the artery of Drummond permits a linear transposition procedure without redundancy or mechanical kinking. It requiresthree anastomosesand thus longer operative time and higher rates of necrosis, morbidity and mortality. Its use is contraindicated in the presence of an aortic aneurysm or extensive atherosclerotic disease involving superior mesenteric artery, previous colon surgery, inflammatory bowel disease or tumours

Jejunum

It is thethirdmost commonly used modality for oesophageal reconstruction. It has segmental vascular configuration making it more difficult to prepare a long segment putting it at a higher risk for ischemia and necrosis. It can be used as an interposition, a Roux-en-Y loop or a free vascular graft

questions.solution:
Injection sclerotherapy is useful for dealing with minor varicosities and recurrence in the calf and lower leg. Though it’s a treatment option for varicose vein, but for a patient of varicose vein with saphenofemoral incompetence and normal perforator, this will be least preferred amongst the given options

Treatment of varicose veins

questions.text: The intracranial tumor most likely to be encountered in a middle-aged man with the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) is:
questions.solution:
Primary central nervous system lymphoma

Incidence is 10% of all primary intracranial tumours and2% to 6% of patients with AIDS.The mean age of presentation is 60 years in immunocompetent patients and35 years in patients with acquired immunodeficiency with a slight male predominance. Presentation is that of symptoms of mass effect and depending on the location sometimes neuropsychiatric changes. The median survival is 2 to 6 months in a patient with AIDS. Treatment consists of stereotactic biopsy followed by radiation therapy and chemotherapy because of their sensitivity to methotrexate

Meningioma

They form 15% to 20% of all intracranial tumours second only to glioblastoma multiforme. They are predominant in females (2:1). The presentation is usually incidental, and they are slowly growing tumours. Meningioma can recur after surgery as described on the Simpson grading system for meningioma resection

Ependymoma

They constitute 5% of all intracranial gliomas. In the paediatric population, they constitute upto 70% of all intracranial gliomas and the peak age at presentation is between 10 and 15 years. In children, ependymoma will typically be present in the floor of fourth ventricle. They are slow growing posterity fossa mass that may cause obstruction of CSF flow leading to hydrocephalus. Treatment consists of maximum possible resection followed by fractionated radiation

Glioblastoma multiforme

Most encountered primary brain tumour in adults. Presentation can include headache, seizures, focal deficits, and personality changes. Imaging demonstrates a ring enhancing lesion with surrounding edema and mass effect. Treatment involves gross total resection with postoperative chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Temozolomide is the current drug of choice

questions.text:

The image shown demonstrates circumcorneal congestion, corneal edema, anterior chamber inflammation with hypopyon. With a history of cataract surgery, the first diagnosis should be post-operative endophthalmitis.

Post-operative endophthalmitis is intraocular inflammation secondary to an infection following intraocular surgery.

MANAGEMENT

questions.text: A 5-year-old baby was brought to the hospital to get vaccinated by his mother. According to the latest guidelines of vaccination, which of the following is applicable for this age?

questions.text: Choose the correct definition of multiphasic screening

choices.text: Application of two or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time
Screening by more than one test done simultaneously to detect more than one disease
Screening test applied on large population

questions.solution:
• Multiphasic screening: application of two or more screening tests in combination to a large number of people at one time. Example: annual health check-ups.
  • Multipurpose screening:screening by more than one test done simultaneously to detect more than one disease. Example: screening of a pregnant women for VDRL, HIV, HBV serological tests on a blood sample.
  • Mass screening: Screening test applied on a large population. E.g.- CXR in elderly.
  • High risk/ selective screening:Applied to high-risk groups. .E.g.- screening for HIV in commercial sex workers.

questions.text: All comprise inherent properties of a screening test except:
questions.solution:
YIELD

  • Yield of the screening test is the amount of previously unrecognized disease that is diagnosed as a result of screening effort
  • Yield of the screening test depends on:
    • Sensitivity of screening test
    • Specificity of screening test
    • Prevalence of the disease in the population
    • Participation of individuals in the detection program

questions.text: Find the false statement about NTEP.

choices.text: MC symptom of PTB: persistent cough ≥2 weeks

questions.solution:

  • Undiagnosed, SS+PTB are the source of infection
  • Most common symptom of PTB: Persistent cough ≥ 2 weeks
  • Main tools for diagnosis: sputum smear, M/E, X- ray & molecular diagnostic test
  • 2 sputum smears examined (spot, early morning)
  • Sputum examined <2 days of collection, results reported on the same day
  • Important to elicit a past history of anti-TB treatment
  • EPTB, contacts of all SS+ve / PLHV with a cough should be subjected for SSM/E irrespective of the duration of cough.
  • 2-3% of new adult OPD (rural PHC setting) will be presumptive TB cases, refer for sputum examination
  • 10% of presumptive TB cases, are found SS+vePTB
  • Grading of smears in helpful as a quality assurance tool

questions.text: A scientist discovered that 4 unrelated factors have a role in the occurrence of a disease. To test the relation between multiple factors and disease which of the following method will be used?
questions.solution:
• ANOVA: Analysis of variance is a parametric test used for the polytomous independent variable
  • Chi-square test: is a non-parametric test used for testing association between 2 or more qualitative variables
  • Multiple linear regression: This is used if the target variables are dimensional having multiple possible values
  • Multiple logistic regression: This is used if the target variables are binary having only two possible values

In the given question, the investigator finds out that 5 independent factors influence the occurrence of a disease. So, to compare these 5 factors one should use multiple logistic regressions.

questions.text: What is the best treatment for the new-onset atrial flutter?
questions.solution:
• Recent-onset atrial flutter: Electrical cardioversionof low-intensity 25-50 J can convert 90% of patients into normal sinus rhythm and is the most effective therapy.
  • In atrial flutter usage of class I agents (Procainamide) will lead to the slowing of atrial flutter to a point where 1:1 conduction will occur, and heart rate can jump up to 200 bpm leading tohemodynamic compromise.
  • Ibutilide:1 mg infusion over 60 minutes will work in 50-70% of patients reverting them to normal sinus rhythm. However, it is not given in the choices.
  • Recurrent atrial flutter:Anti-arrhythmic drugs like sotalol, amiodarone can be used but 70% will experience recurrence. In this situation catheter ablation at Cavo tricuspid isthmus is more effective.

questions.text: 65-year-old male came to the cardiology department with complaint of excruciating pain on exercise which gets relieved on rest. Which of the following test will the physician order first on this patient?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical picture is of Chronic Stable Angina.

]The first test to be performed will be Tread mill test.

Sensitivity

  • PET scan > 95% - best test to identify the viability of myocardium. It helps to differentiate scar vs ischemic hibernating myocardium
  • Thallium scan = 90%
  • Stress echocardiography = 80%
  • TMT = 75% - 1st to be done

Treadmill test [Bruce modified protocol]

  • Non-invasive test
  • Technician will gradually ­speed & ­ inclination (every 3 mins interval)
  • Continuous ECG and BP monitoring
  • Target HR = 85% of maximum possible physiologically = 85% [220-age]

No ECG finding - no blockage

ECG finding ST ↓ > 1mm >80 m sec: 2 contiguous leads

(Down sloping)

↓

Indicated blockage in coronary arteries

Resting, ECG after 3 min of termination of test → post exercise ST segment depression

↓

Indicate blockage in coronary arteries Sensitivity 75%

Hockey stick sign

ECG – Digoxin

Extra mile:

HOCKEY STICK SIGNS
ECG

Digoxin effect
Echocardiography

Mitral stenosis

  • Normal, biphasic, and rapid motion of the mitral valve is altered because it opens only partly and as a single unit.
  • The posterior leaflet becomes immobile and the anterior mitral leaflet tethering results in a "hockey stick" appearance.

MRI Brain

questions.text: A patient involved in RTA was bought to the ER. His Hb came out to be 4 gm/dl. He was transfused a bag of whole blood in 3 hours after which the patient develops breathlessness. Vitals: BP 180/120 mm Hg and pulse rate 110/min. What is the cause?
questions.solution: In transfusion medicine, transfusion associated circulatory overload(aka TACO) is a transfusion(an adverse of blood transfusion) that can occur due to a rapid transfusion of a large volume of blood, but can also occur during a single red cell transfusion (about 15% of cases).The fluid volume causes hypervolemia. The primary symptoms of TACO are dyspnoea, orthopnoea, peripheral edema, and rapid increase of blood pressure. TACO must be suspected when there is respiratory distress with other signs, including pulmonary edema, unanticipated cardiovascular system changes, and evidence of fluid overload (including improvement after diuretic, morphine or nitrate treatment), during or up to 24 hours after transfusion.

questions.text:
Mark the true statements regarding Conn’s syndrome:-

Conn’s syndrome is characterized by Polyuria, Polydipsia and Weakness
Anasarca is not seen in CONN syndrome due to salt escape mechanism
Weakness in Conn syndrome is due to hypokalaemia
Hypertension occurs due to Hyperaldosteronism
questions.solution:
• Anasarca or Generalised swelling is not seen in CONN syndrome due to salt escape mechanism.
  • Though there is gain of salt and water due to aldosterone excess, the increased preload will stretch the right atrium and cause release of ANF.
  • This increase in ANF will cause natriuresis and will cancel the gain caused by aldosterone.
  • This natriuresis or salt loss shall be associated with water loss and leads to Polyuria.
  • The resultant polyuria will lead to Polydipsia.
  • The weakness is explained by hypokalaemia seen in Conn syndrome.
  • Hyperaldosteronism in Conn’s syndrome leads to Hypertension

Hypercalciuria
Generally milder clinical course

questions.text: A patient came in with complaint of watery diarrhoea that even persists on fasting. On examination we found that the patient also had achlorhydria and hypokalaemia. Which of the following can it be?

questions.text: A 70-year-old female came to OPD with complaint of recurrent Herpes labialis and enlarged lymph nodes. On examination hepatosplenomegaly and non-blanching petechiae around then knee was seen. The image given below was seen on peripheral smear. On what medication will you start the patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture points towards CLL (chronic lymphoid leukaemia)

CLL

Clinical features

Median age of presentation: 72 years

Females > males

  1. Progressive cervical lymphadenopathy, night sweats
  2. Infections: Recurrent Pneumonia, Herpes labialis, herpes zoster
  3. Antibodies against self
    • Platelets
      • Non blanching petechiae near the ankles
    • RBCs →AIHA
      • Progressive pallor + purpura Epistaxis
  4. Hepatosplenomegaly (infiltration of cancer cell in liver & spleen)

Work up:

  1. TLC ­ (4K – 11K) – B cell lymphocytosis > 5000 / mL x 3 months
  2. On peripheral smear – SMUDGE cells which are fragile, immune incompetent B cell which breaks down by pressure of glass slide.

3. IOC → flow cytometry CLL → CD19, CD20 (dim), CD21, CD23, CD5

    • B cell presents with T cell marker.

Treatment

  • Low risk, stage A: 75-year-old – conservative management
  • High risk: fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, Rituximab (FCR) or pentostatin, Cyclophosphamide, Rituximab (PCR)

TOC: Allogenic Bone marrow transplantation

questions.text: A 23yrs old, male patient came to your OPD with history of syncopal attacks. He was anxious and revealed about similar history& sudden death in his sibling 2yrs ago. On further work up, ECG showed characteristic ‘Saddle back pattern’ in V1-V2 leads. Which of the following statement is incorrect about this condition?
questions.solution:
Brugada syndrome

  • Due to adiminished inward sodium currentin the region of the RV outflow tract epicardium.
  • A loss of the action potential dome in the RV epicardium due tounopposed potassium outward currentresults in dramatic shortening of the action potential.
  • Thelarge potential difference between the normal endocardium and rapidly depolarized RV outflow epicardiumgives rise to ST-segment elevation in V1-V3 in sinus rhythm and predisposes to local ventricular re-entry.
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, the arrhythmia syndrome is most common in young male patients (-75%) and is thought to be responsible for theSudden Unexpected nocturnal Death Syndrome (SUDS).
  • For patients who have had syncopal attacks,I.C.D. implantable cardioverter defibrillator is usedas it can deliver a DC shock to terminate the arrhythmia developing in these patients and not pacemaker.

questions.text:

questions.solution:
• Statement 1is wrong because the patient should be asked to sniff a mild agent likecoffee or toothpaste. Alcohol or ammonia stimulates the trigeminal nerve which is involved in chemoreception.

Trigeminal nerve endings are typically activated by chemicals classified as irritants, including Sulphur dioxide, ammonia, ethanol, acetic acid, carbon dioxide, menthol, and capsaicin.

  • Statement 2is wrong because ocular saccades utilize cranial nerve 3, 4, and 6 along with PPRF.
  • Statement 3is wrong as eyebrow elevation and forehead wrinkling are done to test the facial nerve.
  • Accessory nervesupplies Trapezius which is involved inShoulder Shrug.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presents with complaints of headache which she describes as the headache was unlike & she had never experienced before & described as the worst of her life. NCCT was done which is shown below. All of the following are true about the condition except:

choices.text: Most common cause of death is re-bleeding

questions.solution:
The above clinical history & imaging findings are suggestive of Sub-Arachnoid haemorrhage.

OPTION C)CAUSES OF DELAYED NEUROLOGICAL DEFICIT IN SAH

  1. Re-rupture
  2. Hydrocephalus
  3. Delayed cerebral ischemia- vasospasm is narrowing of arteries at the base of the brain following SAH. This may cause symptomatic ischemia and infarction in ~30% of patients and is the major cause of delayed morbidity and death. Signs of DCI appear 4–14 days after the haemorrhage, most often at 7 days.
  4. Hyponatremia

OPTION A) MECHANISM OF XANTHOCHROMIC CSF-Lysis of the red blood cells subsequent conversion of hemoglobin to bilirubin stains the spinal fluid yellow within 6–12 h. Thexanthochromic CSF peaks in intensity at 48 hand lasts for 1–4 weeks, depending on the amount of subarachnoid blood.

OPTION B)

  1. frequently shows ST-segment and T-wave changes similar to those associated with cardiac ischemia.
  2. A prolonged QRS complex, increased QT interval, and prominent “peaked” or deeply inverted symmetric T waves are usually secondary to the intracranial hemorrhage.

OPTION D)

Management of SAH

  1. Surgical
  2. Medical management
    • ANTIHYPERTENSIVE
    • ANALGESIC
    • ANTIEIPELTICS
    • STEROIDS
    • ANTIFIBRINOLYTIC AGENT

Treatment with the calcium channel antagonist nimodipine (60 mg PO every 4 h) improves outcome, perhaps by preventing ischemic injury rather than reducing the risk of vasospasm.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man working in a coal mining factory for 27 years develops symptoms of progressively worsening breathlessness and cough with expectoration. On an ABG, pH of 7.2, pO2of 46, pCO2of 80 are indicative of:

• ABG shows severe hypoxia with hypercarbia with acidosis suggestive of type 2 respiratory failure.
  • ARDS and acute asthmaboth haveType 1 Respiratory Failureand are ruled out.
  • So, we have to select between options A and C.
  • Interstitial Pneumonitison routine presentation will not have such low oxygen values but an acute exacerbation of chronic bronchitis will definitely present withlow oxygen values.

questions.text:
Which of the following vasculitis is seen in childhood?

Kawasaki
HSP
Susac syndrome
Giant cell
questions.solution:
Disease in choice Age of presentation and findings
Kawasaki Occurs predominantly in young children; 80% of patients are<5 yr., and, only occasionally, are teenagers or, more rarely, adults affected.
HSP Usually seen in children; most patients range inage from 4 to 7 years; however, the disease may also be seen in infants and adults.
Susac's Syndrome Consists of thetriad of encephalopathy, branch retinal artery occlusions (BRAO), and hearing loss. It usually affects women aged 20 to 40, but men are also affected, and the age range extends from 9 to 72 years
Giant Cell Arteritis Occurs almost exclusively in individuals >50 year

Note:

  • Kawasaki disease has a higher incidence in Indian sub-continental children (OP Ghai Paediatrics, 9th edition)
  • The most common vasculitis worldwide is Henoch Schoenlein purpura
  • In Japan and Asia most, common vasculitis is Kawasaki disease. (Up To Date)

questions.text: To see if the sample mean is an accurate estimate of Population mean, which of the following is used?

questions.text: In this picture of mask ventilation little finger is used for?
questions.solution:
There are several methods for holding the mask to open the airway and a tight seal. The picture shown here is One-handed technique. The thumb and index finger on the left hand are placed on the mask body to push downward to hold the mask to the face and prevent leaks. Remaining three fingers are placed on the mandible or the inferior part of the mask. Finger pressure should be placed on the bony mandible and not on the soft tissues supporting the base of the tongue, which may obstruct the airway. The little finger is placed under the angle of the mandible and used to thrust the jaw anteriorly which pulls the tongue forward to prevent obstruction of the upper airway. This is the most important manoeuvre to allow ventilation to the patient.

Other methods for holding the mask are Two-handed methods, Claw hand technique, Esmarch-Heiberg manoeuvre.

questions.text: A 1-year-old male child, case of dislocation of hip posted for spica cast. Inhalational induction with 8% sevoflurane was done and intubated with a 3.5 mm endotracheal tube. Rationale for using sevoflurane in this case include-

choices.text: Sevoflurane appears to have a greater therapeutic index than halothane
Sevoflurane appears to produce the least degree of airway irritation

questions.solution: Sevoflurane is a fluorinated methyl isopropyl ether. The vapour pressure of isoflurane resembles that of halothane and isoflurane which uses conventional unheated vaporiser. The blood gas partition coefficient is 0.69 which ensures prompt induction of anaesthesia and recovery after discontinuation of anaesthetic. Sevoflurane is non-pungent, has minimal odour, produces bronchodilatation similar in degree to isoflurane and passes the least degree of airway irritation among the currently available inhaled anaesthetic. Sevoflurane differs from halothane, enflurane, isoflurane and desflurane all of which are metabolites to reactive acyl halide intermediates with a potential to produce hepatotoxicity and cross-sensitivity between the drugs and also least likely to form carbon monoxide on exposure to carbon dioxide absorbent. For these reasons, Sevoflurane is acceptable for inhalational induction of anaesthesia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female who was in a case of seizure disorder posted for total thyroidectomy under general anaesthesia. She had to shiver in the perioperative period which was treated with Inj. Pethidine 25 mg IM. This postoperative shivering should be treated promptly because it is associated with-

choices.text: Decreased heart rate and blood pressure

questions.solution:
Postoperative shivering

  • Postoperative shivering is usually but not always associated with hypothermia. Its incidence may be as high as 66% in general anaesthesia. Although thermoregulatory mechanisms explain shivering in hypothermic patients, different mechanisms have been proposed to explain shivering in normothermic patients. Brain and spinal cord do not recover simultaneously from general anaesthesia. More rapid recovery of spinal cord function results in uninhibited spinal reflexes that manifest as clonic activity.
  • Risk factors -young age, endoprosthetic surgery, core hypothermia
  • Postoperative shivering can greatly increase oxygen consumption, catecholamine release, cardiac output, heart rate and blood pressure, and intracerebral and intraocular pressure.
  • Many drugs, notably meperidine, clonidine, and tramadol, clonidine, ketamine, ondansetron can be used to reduce postoperative shivering once it starts. Of those meperidine 12.5-25 mg iv most used in adults. prevention of hypothermia and intraoperative dexmedetomidine infusion are prophylactic measures.

questions.text: Which of the following can cause laryngospasm on induction?
questions.solution:
• Desflurane is the most pungent of the inhalational agent and, if administered via face mask can cause coughing, salivation, breath-holding and laryngospasm. Thus, it is not used for induction.
  • Sevoflurane and halothane both have a good smell thus both are good for induction.
  • Sevoflurane not only good smell, low blood gas solubility so fast speed of induction, non-pungent, has minimal odour, produces bronchodilatation similar to isoflurane and causes the least degree of airway irritation among the available inhaled anaesthetics making it suitable for inhalational induction like halothane thus an agent of choice for induction.
  • Unlike halothane and sevoflurane, desflurane is pungent making it unlikely that inhalational induction would be feasible or pleasant for the patient.
  • The pungency of desflurane produces airway irritation, salivation, breath-holding, coughing, laryngospasm when more than 6% inspired desflurane is administered to an awake patient.
  • Halothane has a sweet non-pungent odour and does not cause airway irritation
  • Isoflurane has a pungent ethereal odour but does not cause airway irritation as it causes some degree of bronchodilatation like sevoflurane

questions.text: A microscopic examination of a thin blood smear was done from a patient suspected of having malaria. An intern was studying the life cycle of the causative agent of malaria in relation to this case. On morning rounds, the intern was questioned by the Duty resident about "what would be liberated by Erythrocytic schizogony of Plasmodium?". His answer should be:
questions.solution:
Erythrocytic schizogony:

  • Merozoitesare released at the end of erythrocytic schizogony.
  • The amoeboid trophozoites after feeding, grows in size and becomes erythrocytic schizont. Asexual multiplication takes place in schizont and forms merozoites which give pressure to the wall of weak RBC and liberated out in the form of erythrocytic merozoites.
  • The process of formation of merozoites in the RBCs from the metacryptozoites is called erythrocytic schizogony.
  • Many merozoites enter the fresh RBC and repeat the erythrocytic cycle.

Pre- erythrocytic schizogony:

  • Sporozoites in liver cells grow and become schizonts.
  • The nucleus of schizont multiply asexually (multiple fission) and forms thousands of merozoites.
  • These gives pressure to the wall of liver cell and liberate out in the form of cryptozoites or cryptomerozoites through the ruptured liver cell.

  • Vaccine strain – Edmonston Jagreb/Moraten/Schwartz

    • Constituted distilled water [BCG – normal saline]
  • LAB Dx – PCR /ELISA for measles virus

→non-septatebroad hyphae

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to a gynecologist for a health check-up and pap smear. She has two live children and does not desire more, on enquiring about contraception she says that she is using this contraceptive pill which has to be consumed twice a week, TRUE about this contraceptive is?
questions.solution:
Centchroman/ Ormeloxifene

Nonsteroidal estrogen antagonist: SERM (Selective estrogen receptor modulator) Developed at CDRI, Lucknow.

Tablets of 30 mg are to be taken twice a week for 3 months and then once a week for contraception.

Has a weak Estrogenic and potent antiestrogenic effect—acting mostly on the endometrial target organs to suppress proliferation of the endometrium, thereby interfering with the nidation of the embryo.

Causes asynchrony between Ovulation and the endometrial development

Other uses: Breast cancer, benign breast diseases, abnormal uterine bleeding

questions.text: A woman presents at 10 weeks for routine antenatal evaluation. The ultrasound at this gestation aims at localization of fetus and viability, however, only a few anomalies can be made out. Which one of the following congenital malformations of the fetus can be diagnosed at this gestation?
questions.solution:
• Ultrasound done in the first trimester helps in dating the pregnancy.
  • Malformations are best looked for at 18–20 weeks of gestation. If there is a malformation that is not viable with a normal life, then a decision to do a termination of pregnancy can be taken at this time (In India: MTP only ≤ 20 weeks)
  • However, in the first trimester, i.e., around 9–11 weeks, gross malformations of the fetus like anencephaly, Acrania, or spina bifida can be picked up.
  • To detect specific deformities like holoprosencephaly or microcephaly, USG is to be done at 18–20 weeks of gestation and not in the first trimester.

Routine first-trimester USG is done for

  • Pregnancy dating
  • Fetal viability
  • Intrauterine or extrauterine
  • Multiple gestations
  • Nuchal translucency and nasal bone are checked at 11-13 weeks (markers for downs syndrome)

questions.text: An ultrasound is done in a multigravida at 30 weeks gestation shows abnormal insertion of the cord and the diagnosis of Vasa Previa is made. What will be the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
VasaPrevia: Color Doppler is the investigation of choice.

A transabdominal color Doppler sonography shows 'flow' in vessels overlying the internal cervical os.

A Transvaginal ultrasound with color Doppler is even better method to demonstrate this.

The APT test is a biochemical test done to differentiate maternal and fetal blood when a pregnant woman presents with a vaginal bleeding episode. Most vaginal bleeding in antepartum hemorrhage is due to abruption and Placenta previa. Placental abruption (32 percent), Previa (21 percent), and cervical bleeding (6.6 percent) were the most frequent causes However when these are not confirmed then to suspect fetal bleeding due to Vasa Previa, an APT test is done.

Here, the vaginal blood is mixed with NaOH, and if the hemoglobin gets denatured (Colorless) then it’s maternal blood.

A positive APT test would indicate that blood is of fetal origin. A negative test indicates that the blood is of maternal origin.

questions.text: NOT correctly matched about types of ribs
questions.solution:
5th rib is a true (not false) rib, as it has a joint with the sternum.

True ribs articulate with the sternum anteriorly, whereas false ribs do not articulate with the sternum anteriorly.

True ribs: 1st–7th (i.e., upper 7 ribs)

False ribs: 8th–12th (i.e., lower 5 ribs)

Note: Floating ribs: The false ribs, whose anterior ends are free (no attachments). 11 & 12 ribs are floating ribs.

Typical ribs: 3rd–9th

Atypical ribs: 1st, 2nd, 10th, 11th, and 12th

Note: The typical ribs have the same general features, whereas the atypical ribs have special features and therefore can be differentiated from the remaining ribs.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the anterior abdominal wall components is correct?

Conjoint tendon is formed by 2/3 of the external oblique and 1/3 internal oblique 
Inguinal ligament formed by aponeurosis of external oblique 
Lacunar ligament is extension of inguinal ligament 
Interfoveolar ligament related to the conjoint tendon
questions.solution:
Conjoint tendon is formed by internal oblique and transverse abdominis and not external oblique and internal oblique.

Other options:

Inguinal ligament is formed by aponeurosis of the external oblique at its lower border. Lacunar ligament is an extension of the inguinal ligament and connects the inguinal ligament to the pectineal ligament near the point where they both insert on the pubic tubercle. Interfoveolar ligament is related to the conjoint tendon Lateral to the conjoint tendon there is a ligamentous band originating from the lower margin of the transversalis fascia and extending down in front of the inferior epigastric artery to the superior ramus of the pubis; it is termed the interfoveolar ligament of Hesselbach.

questions.text:
The roof of the anatomical snuff box is formed by which of the following structures?

Cephalic vein and superficial branch of radial nerve 
Basilic vein and superficial branch of radial nerve 
Cephalic vein and radial artery
Basilic vein
questions.solution:
Roof of the anatomical snuff box is by the cephalic vein and superficial branch of the radial nerve. The pulse of the radial artery is palpable in the floor of the snuffbox against scaphoid bone. - Boundaries of Anatomical snuff box

Posteromedially (ulnar border) - extensor Pollicislongus

Anterolaterally (radial border) - extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus.

Floor - scaphoid, trapezium, base of 1st metacarpal and styloid process of radius.

Content - radial artery (Pulse can be felt by palpating radial artery against scaphoid bone).

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman has an infection in the perineal area. A thorough examination reveals a crack in the upper boundary of the superficial perineal space. Which of the following structures is most likely to be damaged?
questions.solution: The superior (deep) boundary of the superficial perineal space is the perineal membrane (inferior fascia of the urogenital diaphragm). Colle's fascia is the deep membranous layer of the superficial perineal fascia. Deep perineal fascia essentially divides the superficial perineal space into a superficial and deep compartment. Pelvic diaphragm consists of the levator ani and coccygeus muscles.

questions.text: A woman is brought by her husband for an antenatal check-up at 14 weeks of pregnancy. She is a known case of bipolar disorder and has been on lithium treatment. Which of the following fetal anomalies may be seen in her?
questions.solution:
• Lithium effect on pregnant women:
  • Lithium should not be used during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, because of possible teratogenicity.
  • It is known to cause Ebstein's anomaly, a cardiac abnormality.
  • It is characterized by apical displacement of the tricuspid valve, often resulting in severe tricuspid regurgitation, and marked RA enlargement.

questions.text: A woman presents 2 weeks after the intake of medical abortion pills with a history of minimal bleeding after intake of pills. She did not pass any clots or fleshy mass. On ultrasound, there is a single live intrauterine pregnancy. The doctor suggests that she may continue the pregnancy if she wishes, however, there is a small risk of fetal malformation. Which of the following syndromes, the baby may be born with?
questions.solution:
• Moebius syndrome results from the underdevelopment of the VI and VII cranial nerves.
  • It is characterized by facial paralysis and there is an inability to move the eyes from side to side.
  • Most people with this syndrome are born with complete facial paralysis and cannot close their eyes or form facial expressions.
  • There is a strong association between Moebius syndrome and antenatal use of Misoprostol

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with irregular menstrual cycles and anemia is diagnosed to have polymenorrhagia. The menstrual abnormality in the girl is?

choices.text: Increase in frequency of cycle along with excessive or prolonged bleeding.
Increase in frequency of cycle with average normal bleeding.
Increase in duration of the cycle with less bleeding.

questions.solution: Polymenorrhea is defined as cyclic bleeding where the cycle is reduced to an arbitrary limit of less than 21 days and remains constant at that frequency. If the frequent cycle is associated with excessive and or prolonged bleeding, it is called polymenorrhagia

questions.text: Four patients with the following profile are seen at an antenatal clinic. All have a Hb of 8 gm%. Which amongst the following has an indication for parenteral iron therapy?

choices.text: In labor, requiring an immediate rise in Hb
37 weeks, to decrease the duration of oral medication

questions.solution:
Indications of parenteral iron therapy:

  1. Oral therapy is contraindicated
  2. Patient is non-compliant to take oral iron
  3. Non-tolerance to oral iron
  4. Malabsorption Syndrome.
  5. Moderate anemia in third trimester

NOTE: the rate of increase of Hb is almost same as that with oral iron therpy. Therefore, in any condition where quick Hb build up is required, blood transfusion should be considered.

questions.text: The vagina has various defense mechanisms that are most active during the reproductive years of a woman. The bacteria responsible for this vaginal defense has all of the following characteristics, EXCEPT?

choices.text: Estrogen suppresses the growth of this bacillus

questions.solution:
Doderlein’s bacillus:

Rod-shaped gram-positive bacillus which grows anaerobically on acid media, Appears in the vagina 3–4 days after birth and disappears after 10–14 days, Its presence is dependent on estrogen,

The function is to convert the glycogen present in the vaginal mucosa into lactic acid so that the vaginal pH is maintained towards the acidic side.

This acid pH prevents the growth of the other pathogenic organisms.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is correct regarding the use of tocolytics in case of preterm labor?

choices.text: Cervical dilatation >3cm and AOG is less than 34 weeks.
Cervical dilatation <3cm and AOG is less than 34 weeks.
Cervical dilatation >3cm and AOG is more than 34 weeks.
Cervical dilatation <3cm and AOG is more than 34 weeks.

questions.solution:
Latent phase Cervical dilatation ≤3 cm
  • Tocolytics in preterm labour given only in this phase
Active phase Cervical dilatation ≥4 cm
  • Tocolytics in preterm labour cannot be given in the active phase
    • Acceleration phase
    • Phase of maximum slope
    • Deceleration phase

Important information

  • Tocolytics are given when cervical dilatation ≤3 cm and AOG ≤34 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the Contraction stress test/Oxytocin challenge test?

questions.text: Identify the following type of breach?
questions.solution:
• 3% at term
  • Types
    • Flexed (complete breech): can deliver normally
    • Extended (frank breech): can deliver normally
    • Footling (incomplete breech): C- section
  • Most common type of breech: extended breech
  • Best type of breech for vaginal delivery: extended breech (not extended head)
  • Type of breech vaginal delivery done assisted breech vaginal delivery (here we do not touch the baby till umbilicus is delivered)
  • For extended legs in breech delivery: Pinards maneuverer can be done (tap the popliteal fossa and flexing of extended legs is done)

questions.text: Identify the wrong statement regarding the management of Hydrops fetalis?

choices.text: Anti-D administration within 72hrs of the first baby.
300microgram of Anti-D will neutralize 30ml of fetal Blood.
300microgram of Anti- D will neutralize 15ml of fetal RBC.
Anti D is never given prophylactically, only be given after delivery.

questions.solution:
• Hydrops fetalis
    • Management: anti-D administration after delivery of the first baby within 72 hours
    • Dose: 300mg, Anti D will neutralize 30 ml of fetal blood / 15 ml off fetal RBC
  • Kleihauer Betke test
    • Maternal blood in slide acid both maternal RBC will have elution of Hb (Hb goes away) colorless RBC
    • Fetal RBC will resist acid elution so will be in red color (nucleated fetal RBC)
    • If 1% of the slide is contaminated then 1% of maternal blood is contaminated
      • 1/100 of maternal blood = feto-maternal hemorrhage
      • 1/100 x 6000 ml= 60 ml (so 2 injection)

Anti-D is also given prophylactically at 28 weeks (1st dose as the incidence of microscopic hemorrhage increases) ↓

At 34 weeks (another dose)

↓

After delivery (another dose within 72 hours)

    • According to American guidelines: 1st dose given at 28 weeks; 2nd dose within 72 hrs. after delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Laboratory criteria of APLA Syndrome?

choices.text: Lupus anticoagulant positivity on >2 occasions at least 12 weeks apart.
Anticardiolipin antibody titer medium or higher on 2 or more occasions.
Anti-beta 2 glycoprotein-I antibody in medium or high titer on 2 or more occasions 12 weeks apart.

questions.solution:
Diagnosis of APLA

Clinical criteria
  • Vascular thrombosis: ≥1 arterial, venous, or small vessel thrombosis
  • Pregnancy morbidity
    • ≥1 fetal death (at or beyond the 10th week of gestation)
    • ≥1 premature birth before the 34th week of gestation because of eclampsia, severe preeclampsia, or placental insufficiency
    • ≥3 consecutive (pre) embryonic losses (before the 10th week of gestation)
Laboratory criteria
  • Lupus anticoagulant positivity on ≥ 2 occasions at least 12 weeks apart
  • Anticardiolipin antibody (IgG and /or IgM) in medium or high titer (i.e > 40, or above the 99th percentile), on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart
  • Anti-beta 2 glycoprotein –I antibody (IgG and /or IgM) in medium or high titer (ie, above the 99th percentile) on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the OPD with a history of vulval growth. The lesions were initially small growths that have coalesced to form this one large cauliflower-like growth on the vulva. True about this condition are all EXCEPT?

choices.text: Risk is reduced by the use of oral contraceptives.

questions.solution:
• Condylomaacuminata are large venereal warts.
  • Warts are caused by HPV. These warts spread diffusely over the whole of the vulval area and may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths.
  • The growths are seen in women of childbearing age and are mainly sexually transmitted. Vaginal discharge, oral contraceptives, and pregnancy favor their growth.
  • HPV 6, 16, and 18 are implicated in the development of condyloma acuminatum and cancers of the cervix and vulva.
  • In older women it often persists and progresses to carcinoma in situ. Condyloma is associated with vulval, vaginal and cervical cancers in 20% cases.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is on calcium supplementation for rickets and has Genu valgum. When can the child be referred to the surgeon for corrective surgery?

choices.text: When Vitamin D levels return to normal
When serum alkaline phosphatase levels are normal
When serum calcium levels become normal
When growth plate closure is seen radio-graphically

questions.solution:
Treating Rickets with a Deformity (e.g., Genu Valgum/ Club Foot)

  • Resolution of skeletal deformities occurs completely with treatment with vitamin D and calcium.
  • If the deformity persists even afterradiological closure of growth platesin rickets, the child isreferredfor surgery (i.e., corrective osteotomy) can be done.

Genu varumisphysiologicin neonates and infants and reaches its peak between6 to 12 months.During normal growth the tibiofemoral anglereaches zero between 18 to 24 months, after which it turns into a physiologic genu valgus, finally reaching theadult configuration by the age of 6 to 7 years.

Causes ofGenu Valgum:

Etiologies

  • Bilateral genuvalgum
    • physiologic (between 3 - 7 years)
    • renal osteodystrophy (renal rickets)
    • skeletal dysplasia
      • spondyloepiphysealdysplasia
      • chondroectodermaldysplasia
  • unilateral genuvalgum
    • physeal injury from trauma, infection, or vascular insult
    • proximal metaphyseal tibia fracture
    • benign tumors
      • fibrous dysplasia
      • osteochondromas

Causes ofGenu varumin children:

  • physiologic (infants and neonates)
  • rickets (vitamin D deficiency or refractory, caused by hypophosphatemia)
  • bone dysplasia (e.g., achondroplasia)
  • asymmetric arrested growth of the medial distal femur and proximal tibia (e.g., osteomyelitis, fracture, tumor)
  • Blount disease (tibia vara)
  • prior trauma

questions.text: Which of the following statement about phase reactions is false?

choices.text: Glucuronide conjugation is the most common phase reaction
Phase II reaction makes the drug more water-soluble
Phase II reaction mostly catabolic reaction
Methylation is a phase II reaction

questions.solution:
Phase I reactions Phase II reactions
  • Mostly catabolic reactions
  • Includes
  • Oxidation
  • Reduction
  • Cyclization
  • Deamination
  • Mostly anabolic reactions
  • Includes
    • Glucuronide [m/c phase reaction] conjugation
    • Glutathione conjugation
    • Acetylation
    • Methylation
    • Sulphate conjugation

Purpose of phase I – exposure the functional group on the drug

Purpose of phase II – makes the drug water-soluble

Functional groups need not be exposed to some drugs

Eg: Morphine

questions.text: All are true statements regarding Lemborexant except?

choices.text: It is used in the treatment of Insomnia
It is an orexin receptor agonist
It is useful in patients with difficulties with sleep onset/maintenance
The most common adverse effect is somnolence

questions.solution:
• FDA approved drug for the treatment of insomnia which got its approval after two Phase III clinical trials namely SUNRISE I and SUNRISE II.
  • Useful in insomnia, characterized by difficulties with sleep onset and/or sleep maintenance.
  • Orexin neuropeptide signalling system plays a role in wakefulness.
  • Blocking the binding of wake-promoting neuropeptide orexin A and orexin B to orexin receptors OX1R and OX2R are thought to suppress wake drive.
  • Lemborexant binds to orexin receptors OX1R and OX2R and acts as a competitive antagonist with a stronger inhibition effect to OX2R
  • most common adverse effect is somnolence

questions.text: A floppy child came with hypoglycaemia, hepatomegaly, and Cardiomegaly. This clinical picture is depicted by which enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical picture is of Pompe’s disease.

Pompe’s disease

  • It is the only GSD that is a Lysosomal Storage Disease.
  • Occurs due to deficiency of acid maltase enzyme akaacid α(1→4) Glucosidase.
  • This enzyme is present in lysosomes andcatalyses the minor pathway of glycogen breakdown.

Patient has:

  • hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
  • progressive skeletal myopathy
  • Death occurs within 2 years due to cardiac failure

The treatment for Pompe's disease is administration of recombinant enzyme α-glucosidase (Myozyme)
